summary: In Anto v. Mensah, a 1957 Court of Appeal decision in Ghana, the plaintiff sought damages for trespass and a declaration of title after the defendant cut down trees on disputed land. The defendant admitted the plaintiff's ownership of the main farm but claimed he was demarcating a boundary between adjacent farms, inadvertently destroying trees. The Native Court initially ruled for the plaintiff, relying partly on observations from a visit to the site (locus in quo), but the Land Court reversed this, citing insufficient proof of title and undue reliance on non-recorded site observations. The Court of Appeal reinstated the Native Courtâ€™s decision, holding that possession sufficed to maintain a trespass claim where title was not genuinely disputed, and that courts may reasonably weigh impressions from a locus visit when evaluating evidence, especially absent formal plans. It also affirmed that under native custom, boundary demarcation requires joint action by adjoining landowners.
citations: Oyete and Ntim v. Edurnawn and Adno (1956) 1 W.A.L.R. 278
rationaleHighlights: Possession alone is sufficient to succeed in a trespass claim when the defendant does not genuinely dispute ownership of the core land.
A party need not prove root of title if title is not truly in issue based on pleadings or the nature of the case.
Native Courts may attach appropriate weight to observations made during a visit to the locus in quo, especially in absence of surveyed plans.
Boundary demarcation under native custom requires cooperation between adjoining landowners; unilateral action is invalid.
Admission of ownership by the defendant limits the real issue to boundary location, not overall title.
